commentBody:
WOAH! First to comment? Be still my heart. 

Liked this puzzle. Not hard.
Contrary to the clue for SETS ("Women's professional tennis matches have three of them"), I've seen many such matches, including just this past week, that did not have three sets.
For a Wednesday puzzle, finishing in under 10 minutes, I do feel smart. Bravo.
My mnemonic for the colors of the spectrum has always been just, "Roy G. Biv," as if it were a person's name.
So at first glance I had 36D as HAVE A TRY, then HAVE A SIP. The correct answer is HAVE A wait, what? Oh, HAVE AT IT.
Cute. Made me giggle in a fun childlike way.

This puzzle was really good, as was yesterday's.  An embarrassment of riches so far this week.

Certainly the best Tuesday/Wednesday punch ever...?

Great funny, clever, consistent theme.  Only one truly hoary piece of fill (our fine feathered friend).

I would have to nominate both this and yesterday for awards recognition.  I found this one more delightful.
When you don't have a runny nose, it's NOTSNOT.

I predict (or hope, really) that I will not be the only person who parses 36D incorrectly, comes to the comment section wondering what what on earth is happening, and then has a good laugh at themselves when they realize their error.  😂

Sam,

As you may have seen, it’s not just cows that CALVE. Icebergs do, too.
Super fun puzzle. I had to look up Danny Radcliffe and once I had that, the other clues kept me smiling. Been a minute since I so enjoyed a Wednesday puzzle.

Burglar who prefers wearing blue-green instead of the usual black?
TEALERSTEALER

What you might need to demolish the facades of certain apartment buildings?
LEDGESLEDGE

Second hand?
TICKSTICK

Joseph Edy meets English bakery?
CONESCONE

Someone getting buzzed around the printer?
TONERSTONER

Anyway, great puzzle, all mine way inferior to what Cole and Harit came up with. A bit of a fill-in as soon as you got the trick, but rolling with it meant enjoying it. And while the male emus sit around warming the eggs, the females come to New York, do a little shopping and sightseeing, nosh on a few errant Wordplay comments, and come back to their impatient benighted husbands in fine form, ready to raise a new generation of comment-eaters.

I read “Hallmark of a typical Greek tragedy” a little too fast, and it conjured some possible greeting cards:

“Jocasta, Happy Mother’s Day! from Oedipus”

“Jason, Happy Anniversary, love Medea”

“Feel better soon, Prometheus!”

Another clever theme! 

However, I will not be eating liver. 
I will not have just a sliver. 
I will not serve it on my table. 
I may just toss it in the stable. 
I will not eat it on a tray. 
Perhaps I'll give it to a stray. (Cat)

Spend enough time in farm country and you automatically know Calve. My brain wanted Monologue instead of MNEMONIC but that’s due to being a stage brat (as opposed to army brat) given I spent many late nights in a sleeping bag in the aisles while my parents rehearsed. I’m a teacher who spent many years in small towns in eastern Colorado surrounded by farmers so I have a diverse background. Loved Shakespeare clue, Scene, Potter, Act I and karma all meeting at some point. Oh, also lived in Australia for 5 months so emu was a gimme. No help needed tonight and learned a new word OSIER.
I really enjoyed this one (ie got the theme early, no lookups, fastest Wednesday) :)

The COWSCOW came by to pick up that new calf.  First its mom had to LICKSLICK parts of its coat down.  The farmer treated it for pests with a TICKSTICK, right after stopping to clean up after the chickens with the COOPSCOOP....

Then she went to unwind with a beer at the HOPSHOP, picking offerings from the chalked list on the LATESLATE.  She wanted to treat herself well and avoid a CARESCARE.

There are so many of these possibilities you have to fish them out of the water with a POOLSPOOL.

Hey–my momentary befuddlement at getting the 6th letter (after I’d gotten all the others) of the 36 down clue "You try!”, when I was sitting there going “hmm, have a what?”, thinking I was looking for a three-letter word that ended in “it”, instead of realizing I was finishing a two-letter word that began with “a”, gave me a great idea for one of those “this-or-that” clues that some crossword makers sometimes use; “Try this” or “Sow’s offer to piglet”. Get it? I’ll never design a crossword puzzle, but maybe someone who does can use this.

I would really like to understand the relative placement of yesterday’s and today’s puzzles? Beyond the entries and clues seeming much easier today (realizing that can be a bit subjective), today’s is objectively easier because the theme (which is obvious from the first entry) means that once you’ve solved the first half of a themed entry you’ve automatically solved the second half. Nothing against this puzzle as a Monday or Tuesday but yesterday’s deserved a bump up if only for two double stacks and this didn’t seem worthy of a Wednesday.

Is there a name for the phenomenon where the same answer appears in puzzles during the same week, or relative period of time?  ADRATE appears today and Monday this week, but I haven’t seen it in other puzzles.  Is this a pure coincidence, since the constructors are different people and likely not working together, or intentional?  Does the editor have something to do with it?  I notice it from time to time (I actually noticed it a lot more frequently when I began doing puzzles regularly a few years ago) and it always jumps out at me. Sometimes it’s just a common enough crossword answer that it seems unremarkable, but when it happens with answers like ADRATE it seems more intentional.

Our 20th anniversary plans are booked!! I'm so excited and I definitely just can't hide it!! That's what took up my spare time today between working hard for my money! I did, however, do the Tuesday and Wednesday puzzles both today. 

Fortunately, neither took long but both were very nice. I have to admit though, that while I very much enjoyed Tuesday's  vowelingly wowing masterpiece, I had more fun and chuckles doing the Wednesday one. And I do so enjoy funning and chuckling!! Either way, both very fine puzzles in my ever humble estimation. 

I liked that one of the themers was Harry Potter based—with another nod to good ole HP at 47D! Fun!! But each of the themers gave me goofy little laugh!

A sprightly delight to solve this puzzle, but I wouldn't say easy peasy, or a CAKEWALK, just fun.  Clever to tuck in DEBUT, Cole Vandenberg and Harit Raghunathan, but your cluing didn't show that this was yours.  Fresh slants abound around the whole grid.  Thank you, and do give us more.

This was such a great puzzle.  Great puns, working in MNEMONIC as an answer made me feel very smart today. 

Very enjoyable.  Would like to see a rebus puzzle from this creator.  I think they would knock it out of the park.

Good puzzle today, fun theme, not a lot of obscure proper nouns.

Last square I got was OLLIE/DIO cause I had an E there previously.  Also I had trouble with LIVERSLIVER thinking it was LOVERSLOVER and not understanding why for a while.

I never look up answers I don't know but if I'm 80% sure I might look up to confirm, or if I have all the cross clues and have no idea about the clue they form I might confirm that too, and only had to do that today with ASKANT and OSLIE.

My friend makes condiments so quickly, but I'll try to ketchup.

(That was kind of a silly pun, in Heinz-sight.)

Congratulations on a fun NYT debut, Messrs. Vandenberg and Raghunathan! I'm not sure exactly why, but TATER STATER really amuses me.

Good luck in your other endeavors! 

Thanks.
Ohhh. "Have At It".  Got it. "You try!" would have to be used in a very different context for the answer to be what I first read.

In a bit of synchronicity, the obituary of the man responsible for the production design of Potterverse movies appeared in the Times today. Here's an unlocked link. https://www.nytimes.com/2025/09/09/movies/stuart-craig-dead.html?unlocked_article_code=1.k08.jqcM.UoFBmGSmgYvK&smid=url-share
No question mark needed in the clue for CALVE.  There is no pun or misdirection.
I guess I have a dirty mind tonight because my brain did not parse HAVEATIT correctly at first.
The rainbow mnemonic I was taught at my all-girls Catholic school, by a teacher with a twinkle in her eye, was Run Over, You Girls, Boys In View! Fifty years later, I still use it.
A really fun xword!

The Marlow Murder Club is another cozy type British mystery show that has some relation to crossword puzzle setting,, as they say in the show, and solving. 

It's pretty new to me, so I can't give a very thorough review, but so far so good!!

HAVE A 717? (I'm using code because my first attempt to post was unsuccessful, and the innocent word here is the only reason I could think of. I hate being treated like a child in catholic school but here we are). What a weird expression.

I found the clues very straightforward, ditto the theme of rhyming groaners. To me this felt like a Tuesday, and I - the Polish guy - actually solved the puzzle slightly faster than yesterday's, despite never having heard of OSIER and needing lots of crosses for some of the names and trivia.

I thought the clue for OVEN was weird. To me it made it sound like one actually gets into the oven - hands, torso, legs and all - while wearing mitts. I was so confused by the clue I had to rely on crosses for the answer.

We don't really use verbal MNEMONICs over here. Whenever I see an American one, I wonder how remembering a random sentence is supposed to be easier than whatever it is it represents. Of course Polish people utilize mnemonic devices, but visual ones and rhymes are much more popular than the random sentence kind of stuff.
My mnemonic is roy g biv. Sorry. Fun puzzle!
In addition to the meaning cited by Sam, CALVE is also used to describe the action of an iceberg breaking off a glacier or larger iceberg.  Another form of giving birth 😊

Congratulations on your fine debut, Cole and Harit! I’m sharing your puzzle with my sister, a fellow Princetonian (‘94). It was a fun solve. I think you should work on a tricky Thursday (maybe a rebus) for your next submission. You definitely have the skills for it! 🐯

Such a good one! Perfect Wednesday.

Also, I’ve got one: 
Breaking news from the birdhouse?

COOPSCOOP

First introduced to WINK-DINKs (rhyming riddle answers) in the sixth grade.  We used to get a small literary magazine every Friday, and the back page was always a word game of some sort. My mother (who was a great puzzler) and I would play them all weekend. 

That was a long time ago.

I found this delightful crossword to be as nice as yesterday's, slightly easier even. OSIER is used in UK crosswords, don't know why - useful letters?

I'm assuming MAV is a sportsman/woman, and that EDY's ice cream is very famous. Please help with ATTS (didn't watch the programme).

Very nice.

Purrfect p00p?

CATSCAT

Perfect 10 at skeet?

HOTSHOT

Ailing aquatic avian?

WANSWAN

I'll see myself out.
Lovely, lovely, lovely! Found this much easier than yesterday, and quite a delight when the theme clicked. Other highlights: DEBUT, IRONY, and MOTHERSMOTHER. Thanks!

We have a stand of OSIER willow, so that was a nice gimme. We have to keep it fenced off or the alpacas (no LLAMAS here) will eat it.
A fun and breezy offering today, no major sticking points though I did have to look twice at HAVE AT IT. Took a moment to get the first T in the right place.

What is the technical term for the clues in italics?  Anyway, I got them all very early and they were a great help in solving the other clues.  That's a first for me.  Usually, I am not enlightened until the very end.  Enjoyed it!
What a fun puzzle! I especially enjoyed “Heinz bottle blueprint, say”!
Wonderful debut, Cole and Harit. This Granite Stater loved TATER STATER. A young Taj Mahal with CAKEWALK into Town: https://youtu.be/tAPqGZNtXTE?si=6qQ1kZm-k6VQt2FP
I hear "SketchUp" a lot outside this grid. It's a well-known (in certain circles) 3D design application. It pops up all the time in woodworking.
Just right for a Wednesday I think, which isn’t always the case, and a fun solve.
You do not oar a canoe, you paddle.
I have never seen MLADY.  I've seen MILADY and even M'LADY with an apostrophe.  But then I'm sure I'll be overruled.

To crossword/Jeopardy fans.  I believe one of tonight's Jeopardy contestants will be Paolo Pasco, winner of two American Crossword Puzzle Tournaments and top-tier constructor.  He's smart, fast, and knowledgeable and has terrific potential...

Dropped serving dish
PLATTER SPLATTER

Duck theft
TEAL STEAL

I need my coffee to come up with any more.

Fun puzzle, thanks, Cole and Harit.

Loved the wordplay, rhyme, and overall silliness.  These three things have tickled me since early childhood.

Liked the two answers with unlikely first two letters (YKNOW, MLADY).  Liked guessing at the theme answers with as few crosses as possible.

Liked coming across a pair of non-theme answers that could have yielded theme answers: SPOT (for potSPOT), and SPIKE (for pikeSPIKE).  Possible clues -- [Cannabis lounge] and [Certain fish's volleyball shot?].

Loved the obvious camaraderie between the constructors that radiated off their puzzle notes.

Congratulations on your debut, Cole and Harit, and thank you for a fun puzzle, which was, WELL, SWELL!
For the longest time I was channeling Sean Connery on SNLs Jeopardy with 30D.
I loved this puzzle! What a fun Wednesday! Such clever, wordplay within reach of my skill!

A fun one and a great DEBUT.  We recently had another constructor from the Princetonian team, which I think was also a DEBUT.  

I see a lot of nice suggested themers below (HOTSHOT, et al).  Who needs Python?

interesting how crosswords have evolved to be almost more about mastery of trivia than clues that are just clever - it's impossible to solve most without looking up obscure trivia, which is not skill - it didn't seem like puzzles were so trivia-dependent when I started solved NYT crosswords some years ago -

Certain birds--presumably the females, as the males are otherwise occupied--have held up my first post this morning. I'm guessing they disapprove of my mnemonics--why? Was it my message to Kevin, or Mother's diet?

Anyhoo, here's a couple of supplementary themers I've come up with--

["Oops! I've just dropped this tray of delicious, juicy canapes!"]
["Gosh, these TSA agents are getting more and more thorough! First the shoes, then the shoes and socks, and now . . ."]

I'll join the chorus (daddy sings bass). Really enjoyed this one. Typical slow start for me but finally tumbling to the trick was a huge turning point and that's always a nice touch. Still a lot of working the crosses, but that just added to the fun with a whole lot of 'aha' moments when something finally dawned on me. And... a quite amazing puzzle find today. A Thursday from July 10, 2014 by John Guzzetta. Never seen another one like this. Not easy to describe but the theme in this one consisted of some answers with a silent letter in them (e.g. (H)ONEST, LIS(T)EN, I(S)LAND and others. And then in the crossing answer that square with the silent letter was interpreted as being preceded by "SILENT". e.g.: DAM(N)S crossing (N)IGHT - so that was interpreted as 'SILENTNIGHT' And... a couple of other examples; (M)NEMONIC crossing (M)OVIE (silent movie) ELLISI(S)LAND crossing (S)PRING (silent spring) And there were more. Here's that Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=7/10/2014&g=50&d=A ....
If only there were a way to add three people to my subscription. A boy can dream, can't he?

Very fun puzzle! The "gettability" of the themed clues certainly carried a lot of this one for me. Lost quite a bit of time finding that I'd misspelled "DIO" as "DEO" which seemed superficially to work with OLLEE/OLLIE. Oh, well.
You may not see much of me today. https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=cJtL8vWNZ4o
OMG this theme!! It made my morning.  I had all of the themed answers solved except for one, thought it couldn't get any better, and then I hit "Tater Stater".  I'm an eternal fan.
I have issue with the "paparazzi" clueing for POTTER SPOTTER. POTTER SHOTTER makes more sense for that clue and has an added twist of "potshot"

This puzzle did not feel easy for a Wednesday even though I finished it in 20% less time than average.  Maybe it was because, if not for the theme answers, I would have had a lot more trouble coming up with some of the answers.  Even so, I still left 2 independent cells open until the end because I was not sure of them first time around.  There was some stretchiness to some of the answers, all fair, which also may have contributed to the perceived difficulty.  I enjoyed the theme.

Wheel of Fortune mode kicked in at 53A, and I saw TYLER STYLER, who might work backstage at an Aerosmith concert, tying silk scarves to mic stands.

Strawberry Milk is not a great name for a band, are they EMO? I was once in a punk band called Boiled Procedures, so what do I know?

Purrfect poop? CATSCAT

Perfect 10 at skeet? HOTSHOT 

Ailing aquatic avian? WANSWAN

I'll see myself out.
"Otis love interest on Sex Education" what on earth are we doing
Breast feeding baby, go ahead and pout!

HAVE A TIT? What a weird expression.

I found the clues very straightforward, ditto the theme of rhyming groaners. To me this felt like a Tuesday, and I - the Polish guy - actually solved the puzzle slightly faster than yesterday's, despite never having heard of OSIER and needing lots of crosses for some of the names and trivia.

I found the clue for OVEN weird. To me it makes it sound like one actually gets into the oven - hands, torso, legs and all - while wearing mitts. I was so confused by the clue I had to rely on crosses for the answer.

We don't really use verbal MNEMONICs over here. Whenever I see an American one, I wonder how remembering a random sentence is supposed to be easier than whatever it is it represents. Of course Polish people utilize mnemonic devices, but visual ones and rhymes are much more popular than the random sentence kind of stuff.
HAVE A TIT?? I wondered until I realized
Almost a fight tonight, as I couldn't understand why on earth my husband thought the answer might be "have a tit"?!

I didn't parse some of the clues correctly and was horrified to think people in America use HAVE A TIT to get others to try something. Also very confused as to what a CAR GONET was! Thankfully it didn't matter to the puzzle where my mind had put the spaces and I still got the happy music 🎵
Have a tit? A google search only turns up mammary glands. I have certainly never heard this used in reference to the clue.

Cute, I suppose -- but with no surprises.  I enjoy rhyme and wanted this to be both funnier and more challenging than it was.  

On a different subject.  You've heard of the Razzies, a put-down "award" for a movie that's really, really bad?  May I suggest a similar crossword puzzle "award": one for the most forgettable, resoundingly unimportant and inane pop culture clue of the year.  Last week we had some obscure cartoon character's pet some kind of animal, I forget what kind.  Today we have "Otis's love interest on Netflix's Sex Education."  I expect this to be quite a competitive category.

What should we call this "award"?  I give you two choices:

1. The Trivvies
2.  The Poppies

Okay, finally figured out 36D is HAVE AT IT....

World now safe from me trying out new idiom HAVE A TIT 😅

The willow, the love interest and the cow threw me for a serious loop. I ended up throwing some guesses in there and was shocked when I got the music in the first shot lol. A liked a lot of the puzzle but there were definitely a few unlikeable areas.
I had SERVE crossing itself for both 24 down and 30 across for awhile. It worked for a surprising number of crossings.
Is anyone else annoyed at the banner that appears over this crossword that reads:  "Add three  people to your subscription??"  It makes my screen jump when I enter answers.

I thought I came up with a great potential themer, but it turns out "upercalifragilisticexpialidocious" isn't a word.

It would probably be too long anyway. Quite atrocious.
It's a small bird.  What were y'all thinking?  Try to stay abreast of tricky crossword answers.

Fun solve. Good job all! 
As a former Idahoan, I took great pleasure in figuring out Tater Stater!

Loved this one! I thought the theme was super fun. POTTERSPOTTER was what unraveled it for me (super fun cluing there as well). I hadn't ever heard Billy Joel's SCENES from an Italian Restaurant, and after I solved that clue, put the song on and listened while solving the rest of the puzzle. A little less challenging than I was expecting on a Wednesday - still super fun overall!
I’m keeping “Oh, you’re a TATER STATER!”  in my back pocket for the next time I meet someone from Idaho.
I had HA and immediately filled in, "HAVE AT IT!"   My favorite clue was the blueprint from Heinz.

I am not crazy! I know he swapped those grids! I knew it was Mnemonic. One after Nemonic. As if I could ever make such a mistake. Never. Never! I just - I just couldn't prove it. He - he covered his tracks, he got that idiot at the New York Times to lie for him. You think this is something? You think this is bad? This? This chicanery? He's done worse. That Connections! Are you telling me that a man just happens to fall like that? No! He orchestrated it! Jimmy! He Epee'd through a sunroof! And I saved him! And I shouldn't have. I took him into my own firm! What was I thinking? He'll never change. He'll never change! Ever since he was a publisher, always the same! Couldn't keep his hands off of the mini! But not our Jimmy! Couldn't be precious Jimmy! Naticking them blind! And he gets to be a creator? What a sick joke! I should've stopped him when I had the chance! And you - you have to stop him!

Why one would need a mnemonic to remember the colors of the rainbow mystifies me. (Also, since it's continuum, not a series, not all that accurate.) My two favorite mnemonics are

"(Dear) Kevin, Please Come Over For Gay Sex." and
"Mother Eats Squirrel Guts Because She Is Living In Rural Arkansas."

I'll let you figure out to what they refer. Why do the sciences get all the good mnemonics? We musicians get 

"Every Good Boy Does Fine/Deserves Favor."

which is pretty wonky by comparison. Has any culinarian  ever come up with a mnemonic for the mother sauces, in English or in French? I'll have to think on that today, and see what I can come up with.
The constructors friends will be in for a surprise when they show up for dinner but LSD was used instead of shiitakes

Any Idaho residents want to respond to the new nickname?  LOL
Around our house, TATER is our nickname for our Guv, who is leading the state down a path to future troubles and worsening reputation.  

My take on 58D was FORTE!  (A bit louder than just F, though softer than SFZ, sforzando, which means "blow their hair back!")
Ha, ha, silly me.  Musical education led me astray.  I will tiptoe out, pianissimo.

I've read every single one of the comments, and once again, I seem to be the only person who did not like this puzzle. Or maybe the only one to have the courage to be a naysayer. I found it totally boring. The theme answers made it too easy, IMO, and some of them were downright ridiculous. KETCHUPSKETCHUP or MOTHERSMOTHER? ASKANT?? Yeah, it may be in the dictionary, but that doesn't make it au courant.

This was amusing in a silly way. But hey, why not?

"This was the Tuesday puzzle, yesterday was the Wednesday puzzle?" Nah. Shortz just likes to keep us on our toes.

Hey y'all, Thanks for checking out our debut! We're pickled at the amazing response and you make us want to keep on constructing. If you want more Harit and Cole, you should check out Strawberry Milk's first single :) https://open.spotify.com/track/18L4xQ4F4Es2tOddCfZFly?si=df98a286c2be47c8
This is my favorite puzzle of the year. So satisfying to fill out! Good aha moments, tons of humor. 10/10 send more!
Please place a "no thanks" option on your HUGE toolbar ad for us to add family members.  That way, you can keep advertising without making the puzzle impossible to see in full for us PC users.

My kids learned to simply say ROY G BIV, for the colors of the rainbow, so a very straightforward way to remember them. 

However, when I was in school, learning the Great Lakes, we used She Made Harry Eat Onions. That was soooo long ago, but needless to say, it has stuck with me!

My first comment with my new location was eaten by the emus!

I just replied to Lily’s comment, asking if HOMES wasn’t good enough a MNEMONIC.
A delightful Wednesday! Loved ONRYE and the whole theme!! Congrats on a super fun and well constructed puzzle
Delightfully easy for a Wednesday. Thoroughly enjoyed this one!
Can someone help me with the ROCK -> COMIC connection ?    It can’t be The Rock from wrestling, because he’s not a comic, but is there another comic who has that moniker?
I got all of the acrosses first, so when I looked at 36D.........
loved it!  awesome debut good giggle too bravo!
Fun fact: until the turn of this century (and for some even a bit later), judges in superior courts in Canada were addressed as “my lord” and “my lady”. At least they didn’t have to wear wigs.

Loved it. Fresh clues and fill. Ketchup sketch -up was my favorite. 
(I've heard "sketch-up" in conversation before but never seen it in a crossword.)

I was trying to figure out which "Rock" was a COMIC, and had never heard of OSIER so that crossing was tricky for me. Had totally forgotten about Chris, who other than the infamous Will Smith Oscar Slap I haven't paid much attention to since his days on Saturday Night Live.

Re MNEMONIC, mine for the rainbow colors is simply "Roy G. Biv." Easier for me to remember that than the Richard of York sentence. Though in contrast, here are the mnemonics I use for the order of musical key signatures:

Sharps: Father Charles Goes Down And Ends Battle
Flats: Battle Ends And Down Goes Charles' Father

The comments have me LOLing today... the number of people who parsed HAVEATIT differently 😂
I thought the theme was fun, but that Willow/Rock/Netflix character section was my tough spot. Phew! Loved the MNEMONIC clue. 

A trip to Costco may yield an AmpleSample? 😅

I was really stuck in the South because MIENS didn’t makes sense (to me) for 48D and I COULD NOT FIGURE OUT HOW in world HAVE A TIT was the answer You Try! -Until I read the comments! 🤦🏻‍♂️ ugh I need to remember that words are sometimes parsed differently then we first expect. 

Tricky for a Wednesday but still fun

Geology mnemonic:
Creation.
Of
Strong
Dinosaurs
Motivated
Puny
Primates
To
Jog
Cretaceous
Trails
Quietly

Fun puzzle, but a few of the theme answers felt like a stretch.

Like some others, I found the Rock, willow, love interest a tough cross. Never heard of the willow. Also have never needed to know how many great lakes there are (always hated memorization).

Okay - the strangest puzzle I've ever encountered. There are one or two theme answers that I 'almost' get, though not quite. And I'm completely baffled about the rest. Some clue and answer examples: "The end" OMARGARETA "Like aged Beethoven" STOEDWARDEAF "Sarcastic" IRONALDICAL "Emulated Babilonia or Fleming" SKATHARINAD "Fickle, à la M. R. Rinehart" SKITLETITIA "V.I.P." DIGJUANITARY "Goblet" CHAROLDICE "Thingamajig" DINAUGUSTUS Here's the link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=11/2/1980&g=14&d=D Let me know if you figure it out. ...

Cute themers, but, to me, too "generous" a theme for a Wednesday puzzle. Got LIVERSLIVER very easily, and from there it was simple work to fill in the other thematic entries (since getting half an entry was basically enough).

I suppose some of the fill was perhaps a bit too tough for a Tuesday (like ASKANT and OSIER), but to me this was a Tuesday puzzle. Done in about ten minutes, which for me is fast for a Wednesday.

Liked the puzzle, all in all. Congrats on the debut!

Meave and Osier forced me to google. 

I most likely won’t remember them next time.
Have a tit!
have a (.)
HAVEATIT reminds me of a picture of a sign in a bank somewhere on the internet that says “Pen is broken” with insufficient spacing between certain words.
YKNOW I thought there were going to be a lot of complaints about 64a on here.
The alumni magazine for Oregon State University is the Oregon Stater.   Agreed not a common term just giving an example :)
Have two, they’re better in pairs.

Master constructor and world class solver (winner of two American Crossword Puzzle Tournaments), won his debut appearance on Jeopardy tonight.  Smart, fast, and knowledgeable, he shows great promise.

Where he really shined was on an anagram category, where his answers were so lightning quick it almost seemed inhuman.
I see references to icebergs "calving" a lot.

Ooh we’re doing mnemonics? I have a good one. I use a programming language called SAS, and it has a SQL command. This command has a very specific syntax that must go exactly in order. It is:
Select 
From
Where
Group by
Having
Order by

I remember this as:
SAS
Freaks 
Won’t 
Get
Hit
On
10/10 puzzle wow cheers.
I loved this puzzle. Very clever wordplay and not too challenging. Well done guys, I hope we see more from you both!
True dat, Dan. As for SETS, all men's professional tennis matches have three of them.

@Barry Ancona

Not all. Most men's tournaments are best of three (except for the majors and a few others).

@Dan

So is 18D [Women’s professional tennis matches have three of them] just plainly wrong as a clue for SETS?

Curtis,

Mea culpa. I should not have added "all." The puzzle clue, which did not include "all," was correct for men's, not women's matches.

@Dan

On further reflection, I think the clue stands correct as written. When it is said that a tennis match is three sets, it’s interpreted as a best of three, which of course can end after the second set — similar to saying the major league baseball World Series is seven games. Although usually said as a “best of seven,” describing the Series as a seven game series is in the language.

@MExpat I would call them "themed clues" but I'm not sure if that is the accepted nomenclature!

@Mean Old Lady Interesting.  So, what I see on my screen is not what I would see if I printed it out?  And how was it in the olden days when there were no screens?  I did have a print NYT subscription back in the 80s but rarely attempted the crossword, as it made me feel quite out of my depth as a young woman with almost no popular culture background (rural childhood, no newspaper or radio at home, among other things).  Were "theme clues" in italics then? Is that the proper term for them?

@MExpat

When you print the puzzles out to do on paper, you can choose between a "standard layout" or a newpaper version. The newspaper version is exactly like the printed newspaper, but that often makes it cramped on the page and hard to read. So I usually print the standard layout. 

The newspaper version can use italics for some clues. The standard layout cannot do italics.

Italics are sometimes used in the newspaper version for themer clues, especially if there is no revealer clue.

The themers are the entries that carry out the gimmick or theme. They are usually the longer entries, and are symmetric about the puzzle.

Some themes are easy enough to figure out without a revealer. Tougher themes use a revealer clue/entry that explains or hints at the theme.

Today, the five rhyming phrases were the themer entries. Their clues were in italics in the newspaper version. 
There was no revealer today.
